repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - State Pension Systems Reform
            Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the State Pension Systems
            Reform Technical Assistance Project (PARSE4P) for Brazil
            were as follows: the outcome was highly satisfactory, the
            sustainability was highly likely, the institutional
            development impact was high, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            project: PARSEP (I) is an excellent endorsement of the old
            LIL model, one which allowed the flexibility to learn by
            doing. Its success in fact raises questions as to the new
            LIL format, actions based on a driving hypothesis, because
            had it followed that model, it would not have achieved as
            much as it did. Fundamental policy change may have to build
            on initial institutional strengthening. Reforms take time,
            but also that a reform which has languished apparently
            unproductively for a few years may suddenly pick up speed.
            From the beginning this project emphasized information, and
            the emphasis only grew over the course of implementation.
            Design shortcomings (whether as erroneously proposed
            solutions or failures to anticipate new openings) should be
            given a chance for rectification in project implementation.
            This was the advantage of the old-style LIL.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - State Pension Reform Technical
            Assistance Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the State
            Pension Systems Reform Technical Assistance Project is to
            prepare the states technically to address pension reform and
            help them to move through the initial phases of reform. It
            is also to assist the Federal and Sate Governments to choose
            from among the best options and encourage them to implement
            sound reforms. State pension reform comprises four phases:
            (a) technical preparedness and diagnostic; (b) elaboration
            of pension reform proposals; (c) design of required
            institutional framework; and (d) implementation of reform
            proposals. The first project component addresses the
            adaptation of the Pension Reform Options Simulation Toolkit
            (PROST) to Brazilian reality. The second project component
            addresses the training of Federal and state employees in
            pension management and reform and in PROST through the
            support of consultants and workshops. The third project
            component addresses government activities, such as studies
            and dissemination of best case Pension fund management and
            Federal pension obligations and the design of an information
            system linking the Ministry of Social Security and Social
            Assistance with states' pension data bases.
